stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the economy is facing an inflationary gap and/or does not explain that short-run equilibrium real output ($820 billion) is greater than potential real output ($800 billion).
The response states that the economy is facing an inflationary gap and explains that short-run equilibrium real output ($820 billion) is greater than potential real output ($800 billion).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not explain that nominal wages, input prices, and inflationary expectations will increase, which will cause short-run aggregate supply to decrease until real output decreases to potential (full-employment) output.

The response explains that nominal wages, input prices, and inflationary expectations will increase, which will cause short-run aggregate supply to decrease until real output decreases to potential (full-employment) output.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does none of the following:
The response does one of the following:
The response does both of the following:

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the actual rate of unemployment in the short run is greater than the natural rate of unemployment and/or does not explain that the economy is now facing a recessionary gap because short-run equilibrium real output is less than potential real output.

The response states that the actual rate of unemployment in the short run is greater than the natural rate of unemployment and explains that the economy is now facing a recessionary gap because short-run equilibrium real output is less than potential real output.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that a decrease in the government budget deficit will decrease the equilibrium real interest rate and/or does not explain that the demand for loanable funds will decrease because the government does not need to borrow as much (or the supply of loanable funds will increase because public savings increase).

The response states that a decrease in the government budget deficit will decrease the equilibrium real interest rate and explains that the demand for loanable funds will decrease because the government does not need to borrow as much (or the supply of loanable funds will increase because public savings increase).

stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
